conclusion: Three logs A, B, C are stacked as shown in the figure, uniform, same mass m, radius R, top angle of triangle formed by centers is 120 degrees, system in static equilibrium, friction between logs neglected, maximum static friction equals sliding friction.
Log A is on top, logs B and C are on the ground.
The logs form an isosceles triangle with the top angle of 120 degrees.
Need to analyze forces acting on logs and determine dynamic friction coefficient between ground and logs.
Log A exerts forces on logs B and C at contact points, equal in magnitude due to symmetry.
Weight of log A is mg, acting vertically downward.
Each bottom log experiences its own weight mg, normal force N from ground, horizontal force F from log A, and frictional force f from ground.
Forces exerted by log A on logs B and C are inclined at 120 degrees to each other.
Vertical component of force F is F/2, horizontal component is sqrt(3)F/2.
Log A is in equilibrium, so sum of vertical forces equals zero, leading to F = mg.
For each bottom log, normal force N is 3mg/2.
Horizontal force F_h exerted by log A is balanced by frictional force f, leading to f = sqrt(3)mg/2.
Frictional force f is related to normal force N and dynamic friction coefficient mu as f = mu N.
Substitute f = sqrt(3)mg/2 and N = 3mg/2 into f = mu N, leading to sqrt(3) = 3mu.
Solve for mu to get mu = sqrt(3)/3.
The dynamic friction coefficient between the ground and the logs is mu = sqrt(3)/3.
